  • Welcome to Todo project’s documentation!

Welcome to Todo project’s documentation!¶

REST API main¶

async main.healthchecker(db: Session = Depends(get_db))¶

The healthchecker function is a simple function that checks the health of the database. It does this by making a request to the database and checking if it returns any results. If it doesn’t, then we know there’s an issue with our connection.

Parameters:

db – Session: Get the database session

Returns:

A dictionary with the message key and a value of welcome to fastapi!

main.read_root()¶

The read_root function returns a dictionary with the key &quot;message&quot; and value &quot;Hello World&quot;.

Returns:

A dictionary with the key &quot;message&quot; and value &quot;hello world&quot;

REST API repository Notes¶

async src.repository.notes.create_note(body: NoteModel, user: User, db: Session) → Note¶

Creates a new note for a specific user.

Parameters:

  • body (NoteModel) – The data for the note to create.

  • user (User) – The user to create the note for.

  • db (Session) – The database session.

Returns:

The newly created note.

Return type:

Note

async src.repository.notes.get_note(note_id: int, user: User, db: Session) → Note¶

Retrieves a single note with the specified ID for a specific user.

Parameters:

  • note_id (int) – The ID of the note to retrieve.

  • user (User) – The user to retrieve the note for.

  • db (Session) – The database session.

Returns:

The note with the specified ID, or None if it does not exist.

Return type:

Note | None

async src.repository.notes.get_notes(skip: int, limit: int, user: User, db: Session) → List[Note]¶

Retrieves a list of notes for a specific user with specified pagination parameters.

Parameters:

  • skip (int) – The number of notes to skip.

  • limit (int) – The maximum number of notes to return.

  • user (User) – The user to retrieve notes for.

  • db (Session) – The database session.

Returns:

A list of notes.

Return type:

List[Note]

async src.repository.notes.remove_note(note_id: int, user: User, db: Session) → Note | None¶

Removes a single note with the specified ID for a specific user.

Parameters:

  • note_id (int) – The ID of the note to remove.

  • user (User) – The user to remove the note for.

  • db (Session) – The database session.

Returns:

The removed note, or None if it does not exist.

Return type:

Note | None

async src.repository.notes.update_note(note_id: int, body: NoteUpdate, user: User, db: Session) → Note | None¶

Updates a single note with the specified ID for a specific user.

Parameters:

  • note_id (int) – The ID of the note to update.

  • body (NoteUpdate) – The updated data for the note.

  • user (User) – The user to update the note for.

  • db (Session) – The database session.

Returns:

The updated note, or None if it does not exist.

Return type:

Note | None

async src.repository.notes.update_status_note(note_id: int, body: NoteStatusUpdate, user: User, db: Session) → Note | None¶

Updates the status (i.e. “done” or “not done”) of a single note with the specified ID for a specific user.

Parameters:

  • note_id (int) – The ID of the note to update.

  • body (NoteStatusUpdate) – The updated status for the note.

  • user (User) – The user to update the note for.

  • db (Session) – The database session.

Returns:

The updated note, or None if it does not exist.

Return type:

Note | None

REST API repository Tags¶

async src.repository.tags.create_tag(body: TagModel, user: User, db: Session) → Tag¶

The create_tag function creates a new tag in the database.

Parameters:

  • body – TagModel: Pass the tag name to the function

  • user – User: Get the user_id of the logged in user

  • db – Session: Access the database

Returns:

The newly created tag

async src.repository.tags.get_tag(tag_id: int, user: User, db: Session) → Tag¶
The get_tag function takes in a tag_id and user, and returns the Tag object with that id.

If no such tag exists, it raises an HTTPException.

Parameters:

  • tag_id – int: Specify the tag id that we want to get from the database

  • user – User: Get the user’s tags

  • db – Session: Pass the database session to the function

Returns:

The tag with the given id if it exists and is owned by the user

async src.repository.tags.get_tags(skip: int, limit: int, user: User, db: Session) → List[Tag]¶

The get_tags function returns a list of tags for the given user.

Parameters:

  • skip – int: Skip the first n tags

  • limit – int: Limit the number of tags returned

  • user – User: Get the tags for a specific user

  • db – Session: Pass the database session to the function

Returns:

A list of tags

async src.repository.tags.remove_tag(tag_id: int, user: User, db: Session) → Tag | None¶
The remove_tag function removes a tag from the database.
Args:

tag_id (int): The id of the tag to be removed. user (User): The user who owns the tags being removed. db (Session): A connection to our database, used for querying and deleting data.

Parameters:

  • tag_id – int: Specify the tag to remove

  • user – User: Identify the user who is making the request

  • db – Session: Get the database session

Returns:

The tag that was removed, or none if no such tag exists

async src.repository.tags.update_tag(tag_id: int, body: TagModel, user: User, db: Session) → Tag | None¶

The update_tag function updates a tag in the database.

Args:

tag_id (int): The id of the tag to update. body (TagModel): The updated TagModel object with new values for name and color. user (User): The current logged-in user, used to verify that they are authorized to update this item.

Parameters:

  • tag_id – int: Identify the tag that is being updated

  • body – TagModel: Pass the new tag name to update_tag

  • user – User: Check if the user is authorized to delete a tag

  • db – Session: Access the database

Returns:

The updated tag

REST API repository Users¶

async src.repository.users.confirmed_email(email: str, db: Session) → None¶

The confirmed_email function takes in an email and a database session, and sets the confirmed field of the user with that email to True.

Parameters:

  • email – str: Pass in the email address of the user who is trying to log in

  • db – Session: Pass the database session to the function

Returns:

None

async src.repository.users.create_user(body: UserModel, db: Session) → User¶
The create_user function creates a new user in the database.
Args:

body (UserModel): The UserModel object to be created. db (Session): The SQLAlchemy session object used for querying the database.

Parameters:

  • body – UserModel: Create a new user object

  • db – Session: Access the database

Returns:

A user object

async src.repository.users.get_user_by_email(email: str, db: Session) → User | None¶

The get_user_by_email function takes in an email and a database session, and returns the user associated with that email. If no such user exists, it returns None.

Parameters:

  • email – str: Specify the type of data that is expected to be passed in

  • db – Session: Pass the database session into the function

Returns:

The first user with the given email from the database

async src.repository.users.update_avatar(email, url: str, db: Session) → User¶

The update_avatar function updates the avatar of a user.

Parameters:

  • email – Find the user in the database

  • url – str: Specify the type of data that is expected to be passed into the function

  • db – Session: Pass the database session to the function

Returns:

The user object after updating the avatar

async src.repository.users.update_token(user: User, token: str | None, db: Session) → None¶

The update_token function updates the refresh token for a user.

Parameters:

  • user – User: Identify the user in the database

  • token – str | None: Update the user’s refresh token

  • db – Session: Pass the database session to the function

Returns:

None

REST API routes Auth¶

async src.routes.auth.confirmed_email(token: str, db: Session = Depends(get_db))¶
The confirmed_email function is used to confirm a user’s email address.

It takes the token from the URL and uses it to get the user’s email address. Then, it checks if that user exists in our database and if they have already confirmed their email. If not, then we update their record in our database with a confirmation of their email.

Parameters:

  • token – str: Get the token from the url

  • db – Session: Get the database session

Returns:

A dictionary with a message

async src.routes.auth.login(body: OAuth2PasswordRequestForm = Depends(OAuth2PasswordRequestForm), db: Session = Depends(get_db))¶

The login function is used to authenticate a user.

Parameters:

  • body – OAuth2PasswordRequestForm: Get the username and password from the request body

  • db – Session: Get the database session

Returns:

A token

async src.routes.auth.recovered_password(new_password: str, token: str, db: Session = Depends(get_db))¶

The recovered_password function is used to reset a user’s password. It takes in the new_password and token parameters, which are both required. The token parameter is used to verify that the user requesting a password change is who they say they are. If successful, it returns an HTTP 200 response with a message indicating success.

Parameters:

  • new_password – str: Get the new password from the request body

  • token – str: Get the email of the user who forgot his password

  • db – Session: Get the database session

Returns:

A message that the password was successfully reseted

async src.routes.auth.recovery_email(body: RequestEmail, background_tasks: BackgroundTasks, request: Request, db: Session = Depends(get_db))¶

The recovery_email function is used to send a recovery email to the user. The function takes in an email and sends a recovery link to that email. If the user does not exist, then it will return an error message.

Parameters:

  • body – RequestEmail: Get the email from the request body

  • background_tasks – BackgroundTasks: Add a task to the background tasks

  • request – Request: Get the base url of the request

  • db – Session: Get a database session

Returns:

A dictionary with a message

async src.routes.auth.refresh_token(credentials: HTTPAuthorizationCredentials = Security(HTTPBearer), db: Session = Depends(get_db))¶

The refresh_token function is used to refresh the access token. It takes in a refresh token and returns a new access_token, refresh_token pair. The function first decodes the provided refresh token to get the email of its owner. Then it gets that user from our database and checks if their stored refresh_token matches with what was provided as an argument. If they don’t match, it means that either this is not a valid user or someone else has stolen their tokens! In both cases we should invalidate all tokens for this user by setting them to None in our database :param credentials: HTTPAuthorizationCredentials: Get the token from the request header :param db: Session: Pass the database session to the function :param : Get the user’s information from the database :return: An access token and a refresh token

async src.routes.auth.request_email(body: RequestEmail, background_tasks: BackgroundTasks, request: Request, db: Session = Depends(get_db))¶

The request_email function is used to send an email to the user with a link that they can click on to confirm their email address. The function takes in a RequestEmail object, which contains the user’s email address. It then checks if there is already a confirmed account associated with that email address, and if so, returns an error message saying as much. If not, it sends an email containing a confirmation link.

Parameters:

  • body – RequestEmail: Validate the request body

  • background_tasks – BackgroundTasks: Add a task to the background tasks queue

  • request – Request: Get the base_url of the request

  • db – Session: Pass the database session to the function

Returns:

A message to the user

async src.routes.auth.signup(body: UserModel, background_tasks: BackgroundTasks, request: Request, db: Session = Depends(get_db))¶

The signup function creates a new user in the database.

Parameters:

  • body – UserModel: Get the user’s email and password

  • background_tasks – BackgroundTasks: Add a task to the background queue

  • request – Request: Get the base_url of the request

  • db – Session: Get a database session

Returns:

A dictionary with two keys:

REST API routes Notes¶

async src.routes.notes.read_note(note_id: int, db: Session = Depends(get_db), current_user: User = Depends(get_current_user))¶

The read_note function is a GET endpoint that returns the note with the given ID. It requires authentication and authorization, so it uses auth_service to get the current user. If no such note exists, it raises an HTTPException with status code 404 (Not Found).

Parameters:

  • note_id – int: Specify the note id

  • db – Session: Pass the database session to the function

  • current_user – User: Get the current user

Returns:

A note object, which is defined in the models

async src.routes.notes.read_notes(skip: int = 0, limit: int = 100, db: Session = Depends(get_db), current_user: User = Depends(get_current_user))¶

The read_notes function returns a list of notes.

Parameters:

  • skip – int: Skip a certain number of notes

  • limit – int: Limit the number of notes returned

  • db – Session: Pass the database session to the repository layer

  • current_user – User: Get the current user

Param:

Determine the number of notes to skip

Returns:

A list of notes

async src.routes.notes.remove_note(note_id: int, db: Session = Depends(get_db), current_user: User = Depends(get_current_user))¶
The remove_note function removes a note from the database.

It takes in an integer, note_id, and uses it to find the corresponding Note object in the database. If no such Note exists, then a 404 error is raised. Otherwise, that Note is removed from the database.

Parameters:

  • note_id – int: Get the note id from the url

  • db – Session: Pass the database session to the function

  • current_user – User: Get the current user from the database

Returns:

The removed note, which is a dict

async src.routes.notes.update_note(body: NoteUpdate, note_id: int, db: Session = Depends(get_db), current_user: User = Depends(get_current_user))¶

The update_note function updates a note in the database.

Parameters:

  • body – NoteUpdate: Pass the data from the request body to the function

  • note_id – int: Identify the note to be deleted

  • db – Session: Pass the database session to the function

  • current_user – User: Get the user that is currently logged in

Param:

Get the note id from the url

Returns:

A note object

async src.routes.notes.update_status_note(body: NoteStatusUpdate, note_id: int, db: Session = Depends(get_db), current_user: User = Depends(get_current_user))¶

The update_status_note function updates the status of a note.

Parameters:

  • body – NoteStatusUpdate: Get the status of the note from the request body

  • note_id – int: Get the note id from the url

  • db – Session: Get the database session

  • current_user – User: Get the current user that is logged in

Param:

Get the note_id from the url

Returns:

A note object

REST API routes Tags¶

async src.routes.tags.create_tag(body: TagModel, db: Session = Depends(get_db), current_user: User = Depends(get_current_user))¶
The create_tag function creates a new tag in the database.

The function takes a TagModel object as input, which is validated by pydantic. The function also requires an authenticated user to be passed in via the current_user parameter.

Parameters:

  • body – TagModel: Validate the body of the request

  • db – Session: Access the database

  • current_user – User: Get the current user from the database

Returns:

A tagmodel object

Doc-author:

Trelent

async src.routes.tags.read_tag(tag_id: int, db: Session = Depends(get_db), current_user: User = Depends(get_current_user))¶

The read_tag function is used to retrieve a single tag from the database. It takes in an integer representing the ID of the tag, and returns a Tag object.

Parameters:

  • tag_id – int: Specify the tag id to be read

  • db – Session: Pass the database session to the function

  • current_user – User: Ensure that the user is logged in

Returns:

A tag object

Doc-author:

Trelent

async src.routes.tags.read_tags(skip: int = 0, limit: int = 100, db: Session = Depends(get_db), current_user: User = Depends(get_current_user))¶

The read_tags function returns a list of tags.

Parameters:

  • skip – int: Skip the first n tags

  • limit – int: Limit the number of tags returned

  • db – Session: Get the database session

  • current_user – User: Get the current user from the auth_service

Returns:

A list of tags

async src.routes.tags.remove_tag(tag_id: int, db: Session = Depends(get_db), current_user: User = Depends(get_current_user))¶

The remove_tag function removes a tag from the database.

Parameters:

  • tag_id – int: Get the tag id from the url

  • db – Session: Get the database session

  • current_user – User: Get the user who is currently logged in

Returns:

A dict, but the schema is not specified

Doc-author:

Trelent

async src.routes.tags.update_tag(body: TagModel, tag_id: int, db: Session = Depends(get_db), current_user: User = Depends(get_current_user))¶
The update_tag function updates a tag in the database.
The function takes three arguments:

body (TagModel): A TagModel object containing the new values for the tag. tag_id (int): An integer representing the ID of an existing tag to be updated. db (Session, optional): A SQLAlchemy Session object used to query and update data in a database. Defaults to None, which will cause Depends(get_db) to create one when called by FastAPI’s dependency injection system.

Parameters:

  • body – TagModel: Get the data from the request body and

  • tag_id – int: Specify the id of the tag to be deleted

  • db – Session: Access the database

  • current_user – User: Get the current user from the database

Returns:

A tagmodel object

Doc-author:

Trelent

REST API routes Users¶

async src.routes.users.read_users_me(current_user: User = Depends(get_current_user))¶

The read_users_me function is a GET endpoint that returns the current user’s information.

Parameters:

current_user – User: Get the current user

Returns:

The current user object

async src.routes.users.update_avatar_user(file: UploadFile = File(PydanticUndefined), current_user: User = Depends(get_current_user), db: Session = Depends(get_db))¶
The update_avatar_user function is used to update the avatar of a user.

The function takes in an UploadFile object, which contains the file that will be uploaded to Cloudinary. It also takes in a User object, which is obtained from auth_service’s get_current_user function. Finally it takes in a Session object, which is obtained from get_db().

Parameters:

  • file – UploadFile: Upload the file to cloudinary

  • current_user – User: Get the current user’s email

  • db – Session: Connect to the database

Returns:

The user object with the updated avatar

REST API service Auth¶

class src.services.auth.Auth¶

Bases: object

ALGORITHM = 'HS256'¶
SECRET_KEY = '1234567890'¶
async create_access_token(data: dict, expires_delta: float | None = None)¶
The create_access_token function creates a new access token.
Args:

  • data (dict): A dictionary containing the claims to be encoded in the JWT.

  • expires_delta (Optional[float]): An optional parameter specifying how long, in seconds, the access token should last before expiring. If not specified, it defaults to 15 minutes.

Parameters:

  • self – Represent the instance of a class

  • data – dict: Pass the data to be encoded in the token

  • expires_delta – Optional[float]: Set the expiration time of the access token

Returns:

An encoded access token

async create_email_token(data: dict)¶

The create_email_token function takes in a dictionary of data and returns a token. The token is created using the JWT library, which encodes the data into a string that can be decoded later. The function also adds an expiration date to the encoded data.

Parameters:

  • self – Make the function a method of the class

  • data – dict: Pass in the data that will be encoded

Returns:

A token that is signed with the secret_key

async create_refresh_token(data: dict, expires_delta: float | None = None)¶
The create_refresh_token function creates a refresh token for the user.
Args:

data (dict): A dictionary containing the user’s id and username. expires_delta (Optional[float]): The time in seconds until the token expires. Defaults to None, which sets it to 7 days from now.

Parameters:

  • self – Make the function a method of the class

  • data – dict: Pass in the data that we want to encode into the token

  • expires_delta – Optional[float]: Set the expiration time for the refresh token

Returns:

A refresh token

async decode_refresh_token(refresh_token: str)¶

The decode_refresh_token function is used to decode the refresh token. It will raise an exception if the token is invalid or has expired. If it’s valid, it returns the email address of the user.

Parameters:

  • self – Represent the instance of a class

  • refresh_token – str: Decode the refresh token

Returns:

The email of the user

async get_current_user(token: str = Depends(OAuth2PasswordBearer), db: Session = Depends(get_db))¶
The get_current_user function is a dependency that will be used in the

protected endpoints. It takes a token as an argument and returns the user if it’s valid, otherwise raises an HTTPException with status code 401.

Parameters:

  • self – Access the class attributes

  • token – str: Pass the token from the request header

  • db – Session: Pass the database session to the function

Returns:

A user object

async get_email_from_token(token: str)¶

The get_email_from_token function takes a token as an argument and returns the email address associated with that token. The function uses PyJWT to decode the token, which is then used to retrieve the email address from its payload.

Parameters:

  • self – Represent the instance of the class

  • token – str: Pass the token that is sent to the user’s email

Returns:

The email that was encoded in the jwt token

get_password_hash(password: str)¶

The get_password_hash function takes a password as input and returns the hash of that password. The hash is generated using the pwd_context object, which is an instance of Flask-Bcrypt’s Bcrypt class.

Parameters:

  • self – Represent the instance of the class

  • password – str: Specify the password that we want to hash

Returns:

A hash of the password

oauth2_scheme = <fastapi.security.oauth2.OAuth2PasswordBearer object>¶
pwd_context = <CryptContext>¶
r = Redis<ConnectionPool<Connection<host=localhost,port=6379,db=0>>>¶
verify_password(plain_password, hashed_password)¶

The verify_password function takes a plain-text password and hashed password as arguments. It then uses the pwd_context object to verify that the plain-text password matches the hashed one.

Parameters:

  • self – Represent the instance of the class

  • plain_password – Compare the password entered by the user to see if it matches

  • hashed_password – Compare the hashed password stored in the database to the plain text password entered by a user

Returns:

True if the password is correct and false otherwise

REST API service Email¶

async src.services.email.send_email(email: EmailStr, username: str, host: str)¶
The send_email function sends an email to the user with a link to confirm their email address.
The function takes in three parameters:

-email: EmailStr, the user’s email address. -username: str, the username of the user who is registering for an account. This will be used in a greeting message within the body of the email sent to them. -host: str, this is used as part of a URL that will be included in an HTML template for sending emails.

Parameters:

  • email – EmailStr: Specify the email address of the recipient

  • username – str: Pass the username to the template

  • host – str: Pass in the hostname of the server to be used in the email template

Returns:

A coroutine object

async src.services.email.send_recovery_email(email: EmailStr, username: str, host: str)¶
The send_recovery_email function sends an email to the user with a link to reset their password.
Args:

email (str): The user’s email address. username (str): The user’s username. host (str): The hostname of the server where this function is being called from.

Parameters:

  • email – EmailStr: Specify the email address of the user

  • username – str: Personalize the email message

  • host – str: Pass the host url to the template

Returns:

A coroutine object, which is a special type of object that can be used with asyncio
